Summary Please note that the below is out of date, but does still hold some relevance. I will be updating soon. 
 
I am currently an undergraduate computer science student at San Jose State University (SJSU). I am an avid follower of new technologies and enjoy exploring the possible applications of these new developments. I have dedicated the majority of my free time to researching new technologies, obtaining leadership positions and gaining software development experience. Throughout my academics years at SJSU I have been involved with several organizations, such as the Entrepreneurial Society where I have held a position as the Technical Officer. Furthermore, I often find myself developing applications for the Android mobile platform, two of which have already been released to the Google Play app store. I have previously worked as an intern at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. I have also currently hold a position at Cisco Systems as an IT Engineer intern. Currently I am working on developing a mobile application. I truly hope to be on the forefront of technological developments and to create innovative technologies that will impact the world in a positive way. During the creation of these proof of concepts, I was able to use various new technologies and choose the best for the specific job. Some of these included, Node.JS, Express, AngularJS and MongoDB. I have also used a java framework called Play 2.0 and various other web technologies. 
 
One of my main projects was the Product Comparison Tool. The primary purpose of this web application is to compare Cisco products, such as routers and switches, against other competitor products so that Cisco sales personnel may easily identify competitive advantages. 
 
For many of my projects I was responsible for the system administration for the given systems, using VMware EXSi. The primary operating system of choice was CentOS. 
 
Software design patterns and architectures include, REST and Client MVC. For unit testing in Node.JS and AngularJS, the following frameworks were used, Mocha, Karma, and Expect.JS. For code review and source control, we used Gerrit and GIT.
